posts.name: Bella Cucina
posts.note: From the Bella Cucina website, 'In the early nineties, Alisa Barry opened a café in Atlanta to share her passion for cooking and eating as an artful ritual. Inspired by her culinary training in California and sabbaticals in the hill towns of Italy, she created a simple menu made with locally sourced ingredients. When her loyal customers kept asking to take home her artful offerings, an artisan food business was born. Bella Cucina Artful Food is an all-natural, artisan product line available in lifestyle gift and specialty food stores around the world. Bella Cucina believes beauty extends beyond the table and into the home.'

posts.name: Bone Garden Cantina
posts.note: Bone Garden Cantina has a Day of the Dead decor meets a homestyle Mexican menu and margaritas at this hip, lively cantina. You need to order their cactus tamale or mole tacos/burritos. From their website, 'Day of the Dead or “Dia de Los Muertos” is an ancient custom of honoring ancestors and departed loved ones during the days of October 31st through November 2nd. Observed with reverence and excitement across Mexico, the celebrations and gatherings of friends and family reveal a uniquely positive outlook on life. Tequila and Mezcal have been a part of this tradition for centuries, as Mexico has a rich history of producing the oldest distilled spirit in the western hemisphere. Bone Garden Cantina offers many opportunities to enjoy and discover Agave Spirits through an extensive menu selection, delicioso cocktails, ongoing Tequila Tastings, Mezcal workshops, and educational information.'

posts.name: Buford Highway Farmers Market
posts.note: The Buford Highway Farmers Market is a spacious market with a global and ethnic focus on the selection of produce, meats, and seafood. From the Atlanta Eater website, ‘The sprawling market on Buford Highway includes everything from fresh produce and meats to foodstuffs, spices, and pantry goods from Mexico, Central and South America, West Africa, Japan, China, and Thailand. Buford Highway Farmers Market encompasses over 100,000 square feet selling a variety of fresh produce, meat, and seafood and offering aisles filled with products and ingredients from around the world. There’s often fresh-made dumplings, along with other prepared foods found at the back counter, too.’

posts.name: Busy Bee Cafe
posts.add1: 810 Martin Luther King Jr Dr NW
posts.note: Busy Bee Cafe is a circa-1947 downtown classic that still serves traditional soul food at budget prices in a cozy storefront. You need to order the fried chicken. From their website,'Lines for fried chicken and other soul food classics tend to get long at this Vine City restaurant institution, especially on the weekends. The move is to head here on a Monday for some of the city’s best-fried chicken, alongside an assortment of other Southern meat-and-three staples. The fried chicken at Busy Bee is marinated for 12 hours, hand-breaded, and fried. If that isn’t enticing enough, get the smothered version, which is topped with pan gravy.'

posts.name: El Taco Veloz
posts.note: El Taco Veloz strives to deliver the best in high-value, low-priced authentic Mexican food. From their website, 'Since our opening on November 1991 in the heart of Buford Hwy, Taco Veloz has been offering the best of traditional and popular Mexican street food. With all the textures, colors, flavors, and smells, our food is irresistible for any food palate. Every item is made with the highest quality and freshest ingredients. Taco Veloz was accepted from day one by the community. Long lines flooded the taqueria to get a taste of our delicious tacos, tortas, burritos, nachos and aguas frescas. This is what has motivated us to continue to grow the business and provide our products all around Atlanta.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Fat Matt's Rib Shack
posts.note: Fat Matt's Rib Shack is a no-frills counter-service beer and BBQ joint with nightly live blues music. From their website, 'Fat Matt’s, An Electric And Unpretentious Blues And Barbecue Joint Specializes In Ribs, From Sandwich To Slab, And A Long List Of Special Sides. Nightly Live Acts, Slab Of Award-Winning Ribs and Sweet Potato Pie.' From theAtlanta Eater website, 'Heralded by the late Anthony Bourdain, Fat Matt’s Rib Shack on Piedmont often features a line out the door. Don’t be deterred. It moves fast. Order a slab of pork ribs with sides of “rum” baked beans, collards, and mac and cheese while listing to live blues music.'

posts.name: Fellini's Pizza
posts.note: Fellini's Pizza is a relaxed pizzeria that draws a mixed crowd with pies, a colorful interior, and a patio with a fountain. From the Atlanta Eater website, 'At $2.75 a (massive) slice, one or two helpings here and a drink with friends makes for a great pizza spot. With seven locations around town and late-night hours, Fellini’s has become an Atlanta staple for affordable and delicious pizza.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Folk Art
posts.note: Folk Art is a brick-walled spot with vintage decor whipping up home-style fare and cocktails with a stylish twist. You should order the meatball burger which comes with three patties, sauteed onions, and mushrooms. From their website, 'The original Inman Park location is sure to present people with a bit of a wait, but it’s worth it. Folk Art has earned a reputation for having some of the best brunch fare in Atlanta since opening in 2013. Having opened a second location in Decatur in the former Thumbs Up space, Folk Art continues to pull in throngs of patrons there, too. Look for plates of Southern brunch fixings on the menu, like deep-fried cheddar jalapeno grit fritters, Angus beef patty melts, and roasted pork and chilis over eggs and queso. Don’t shy away from the staples at this restaurant, including the three-egg omelets and whiskey compote waffle with fried chicken. The latter totally stands up to fierce competition in this chicken-and-waffle-crazed town. Start your day the right way with one of Folk Art’s famous breakfast options. House-made Biscuits (of course) and savory breakfast sandwiches, fluffy waffles, and perfect omelettes, paired with a side of our one-of-a-kind Hash “itout” Browns, and too many more delicious choices to list. Folk Art is your new go-to breakfast/brunch spot. We serve breakfast all day, so is breakfast for dinner is your jam, we’ve got you covered.'

posts.name: Fox Bros. Bar-B-Q
posts.note: Fox Bros. Bar-B-Q serves the Texan brothers' slow-roasted ribs, pulled pork, and Southern sides in an informal space with a patio. You need to order their brisket burger from what I have been told. Here's a quote from their website: 'Growing up in Texas, Jonathan and Justin Fox were inspired by the open sky, the Texas heat, and the southern spice. With no professional training, the self-taught, identical twins developed a passion for cooking for friends and family.'

posts.name: Gato
posts.note: Gato is a funky, snug Tex-Mex cafe serving breakfast and& lunchtime sandwiches in diner digs with checked floors. Here's more information about Gato from the Atlanta Eater website, 'This cozy neighborhood restaurant on the corner of McClendon Avenue and Clifton Road in Candler Park is owned by Nicholas Stinson and offers a Southwestern-influenced breakfast and lunch throughout the week. For nearly a decade, Gato has served as a restaurant incubator on weekend evenings for moonlighting chefs. Stinson now offers his own dinner series called “Gato Nights” (Thursday - Sunday) exploring the regional food roots of southern Mexico and the Yucatán. Come here for natural and biodynamic wines, too.

posts.name: The General Muir
posts.note: The General Muir is a New York-style deli goes contemporary at this upscale Jewish deli adorned with subway tiles. Order the smoked pastrami hash with sunny side eggs on top or a platter which are served with capers, red onion, olives, and a choice of schmear and a bagel. The Lower Eastside lox (salt-cured), Nova (smoked), smoked trout salad or the Maven lox (salt-cured), Nova (smoked), sable, baked salmon salad. From tehir website, 'The General Muir is a modern American restaurant inspired by classic New York Jewish deli, returning it to its hand-crafted roots. Traditional favorites are honored — pastrami is cured and smoked in-house, bagels are hand-rolled and kettle boiled — and joined by dishes going beyond tradition, focusing on fresh ingredients and simple preparations. The restaurant is named for the refugee transport ship that brought co-owner Jennifer Johnson's mother and grandparents, Holocaust survivors, to New York in 1949.'

posts.name: The Grey
posts.note: The Grey is a high-end retro venue with two bars offering modern Southern eats in a refurbished Greyhound bus depot. From their website, 'Welcome to The Grey. Occupying a 1938 art deco Greyhound Bus Terminal that they painstakingly restored to its original luster, The Grey offers a food, wine, and service experience that is simultaneously familiar and elevated. Bringing her personal take on Port City Southern food to a city of her youth allows The Grey to offer dishes that are deep, layered, and soulful in their flavors. With a penchant for regional produce, seafood and meats, guests will find a melting pot of surprising and comforting tastes with something new revealed in each and every visit.'

posts.name: The Grey Market
posts.note: The Grey Market combines a Southern lunch counter and New York City-style bodega — bringing a 'come as you are, for anything you need' spirit to a genre made famous as a site of segregation. The Grey Market will serve Savannahians seafood boudin po’ boys, rare roast beef sandwiches, and a curry chicken salad (inspired by the Grey’s Chicken Country Captain) to-go. From their website, 'Johno Morisano and Mashama Bailey opened The Grey in 2014 and immediately landed themselves and Savannah on the national food map receiving a number of accolades that include, among a long list of others, a James Beard semifinalist nod as Best New Restaurant in America, Eater.com’s Restaurant of the Year for 2017/18 and Time Magazine’s Top 100 Places in the World in 2018. Mashama received her first James Beard nomination as Best Chef – Southeast in 2018. '

posts.name: Hankook Taqueria
posts.note: Hankook Taqueria is a fast-food eatery, born from a taco truck, serving casual Korean-Mex fusion fare. From what I heard, you should order the Korean fried chicken tacos and the Bulgogi Kimchi fries. From their website, ‘Hankook is where it all started. Chef Tomas Lee brought the combined flavors of Korea and Mexico to Atlanta in this off-the-beaten-path location in the westside of Atlanta.” From the Atlanta Eater website, ‘Hankook Taqueria was born from a food truck and bills itself as a Korean-Mexican fusion restaurant with an assortment of Korean barbecue tacos and burritos. This no-frills taco shop has become a mainstay on Collier Road in Westside. Try the spicy pork or chicken tacos or burritos with Korean-marinated meats. Don’t forget to order sesame fries. For something with a bit of kick, order the spicy firedog with green cabbage kimchi.’

posts.name: Heirloom Market BBQ
posts.note: Heirloom Market BBQ is a tiny eatery with a single communal table offering BBQ and burgers with a slight Asian accent. You should get the spicy BBQ sandwich. From the Atlanta Eater website, ‘This Cobb County barbecue spot has limited seating, but chefs and owners Cody Taylor and Jiyeon Lee bring more than enough flavor to compensate for the cramped quarters or a ride home with a to-go box. Taylor and Lee’s Southern-Korean barbecue restaurant offers a must-try spicy Korean pork sandwich on its menu with chopped rib meat marinated in fermented chile paste, topped with kimchi coleslaw, black sesame seeds, and a sliced scallion. Order the sandwich with a side of Brunswick stew, cucumber radish salad, or kimchi slaw.’

posts.name: Joy Cafe
posts.note: Joy Cafe is a locally–run cafe serving sandwiches, salads, and they serve a weekend brunch in a comfy setting with a patio. You need to order the shrimp and grits or the biscuits and gravy with chorizo and cheesy hash browns. From their website, 'Our attention to detail ensures quality while keeping foods preservative-free. Our recipes have been handed down from generation to generation, and now we bring them to you!. We're always cooking up amazing food at Joy Cafe, whether you're in the mood for a life-changing grilled cheese or a decadent berry breakfast waffle. Our seasonal offerings are always changing, too.'

posts.name: Metro Coffee House
posts.note: MFrom the Visit Augusta website, ‘Metro A Coffeehouse and Pub (aka “Metro”) is a rustic, personality-filled landmark location in Downtown Augusta, Georgia. Cultivated by locals and visitors alike, Metro is a place to gather as one to drink premium coffee, beer, and mixed spirits, a place to be together and worry about very little.’

posts.name: Narobia's Grits and Gravy
posts.note: Narobia's Grits and Gravy is a modest, down-home joint serving American comfort and soul foods for breakfast, brunch, and lunch. I saw Narobia's Grits and Gravy restaurant on Mashama Bailey's episode of Chef's Table on Netflix. Order the shrimp and grits with eggs over easy on top.

posts.name: New Moon Cafe
posts.note: New Moon Cafe is an upbeat cafe offering freshly roasted coffee beans and a menu of housemade pastries, soups, and entrees. From their website, ‘We are serving up creative comfort food using fresh, honest ingredients from around the southeast. We roast our own coffee in small batches, bake our bread and pastries in-house and make our soups from scratch every day. We’re also proud to serve the best of what we don’t make in-house, like Ghirardelli chocolate, Boar’s Head meats and cheeses, and American-grown teas from the Charleston Tea Garden. New Moon is an innovative culinary family fueled by community and a passion for bringing people together over great food & the perfect cup of coffee.’

posts.name: Nina and Rafi
posts.note: Nina and Rafi serve rustic Italian eatery and pizzeria with brunch and a full bar, including an extensive amaro collection. From the Atlanta Journal-Constitution website, 'Atlanta’s most popular pizza maker grew up spending summers on the central Jersey shore with his grandma. To make money, he worked at his Uncle David’s pizzeria in Red Bank, New Jersey, a place called Franciosi’s, where he rolled out his first pie around the age of 12 or 13. Truth be told, he didn’t love the work, which required him to labor next to a scorching hot oven for 60 to 70 hours a week. “It was always a job to fall back on, but it was always a job I kinda fought,” he says.'

posts.name: One Flew South
posts.add2: Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport (ATL) - Concourse E
posts.note: One Flew South serves well-prepared Asian-tinged rooty southern chow is their thing. Think pulled-duck confit sandwich with toasted peanut relish and scallion. Don’t miss their house-cured salmon bruschetta. They serve real restaurant food, not the type of thing typically found being done well in airports, and in this sense, it has been the inspiration and the outlier for a whole new wave of foodservice trends in the travel space. One Flew South is a frequent fliers' favorite stop eclectic/Southern spot at Atlanta airport's Concourse E. From their website, ‘One Flew South™ is the first upscale dining experience in Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. Diners can enjoy spirited global fare featuring premium ingredients from regional farmers and purveyors. One Flew South™ serves proper cocktails and features an exceptional sushi menu and takeaway items. The restaurant presents an enticing culinary destination for travelers braving the world’s busiest airport.’

posts.name: The Optimist
posts.note: The Optimist serves lobster rolls, gumbo, wood-fired oysters, and more in a lofty, country-modern space. You need to try the lobster rolls and shrimp toast for the toast alone. From their website, ‘Ford Fry’s The Optimist brings a seaside fish camp experience to landlocked Atlantans. From fresh oysters from the Alabama coast and Maine sea scallops to whole roasted Georgia trout, guests enjoy high-quality, sustainable seafood from the country’s best suppliers. Tucked in an old ham-aging house, The Optimist serves up beer, wine, and handcrafted cocktails with hickory-roasted fish and raw oysters, while beach-food classics like hush puppies and lobster rolls transport you to your favorite coastal haunts.’

posts.name: Pijiu Belly
posts.note: From their website, ‘Pijiu Belly (“pijiu” meaning “beer” in Mandarin) was created by the Shou Family. The Shou siblings grew up in restaurants owned by their parents, and over their 25-year career as restaurateurs, they’ve created several local successes. However, they had a dream... To infuse an English Gastropub with cuisine & hospitality from their family’s Korean-Chinese heritage. As you can see, Pijiu Belly delivers an experience right in line with that vision - Korean-Chinese dishes, great beer-wine-cocktail options’

posts.name: Ponce City Market
posts.note: Ponce City Market is a mixed-use development located in a historic building in Atlanta, with national and local retail anchors, restaurants, a food hall, boutiques and offices, and residential units. From their website, 'At the heart of Ponce City Market, the Central Food Hall is becoming the most vibrant food hall and market in the Southeast. James Beard Award-winning chefs, the likes of Anne Quatrano, Linton Hopkins, and Sean Brock join Atlanta’s most exciting young purveyors and restauranteurs to offer everything from Georgia and Carolinas-caught seafood, to classic burgers, cold-pressed juice, house-made pasta, and freshly milled heirloom grain bread. Similar to the legendary food hall at Chelsea Market in Manhattan—also owned by the developers of Ponce City Market—the Central Food Hall is a culinary gathering place within a revamped historic space, but with the distinct character and ﬂavors of Atlanta.'

posts.name: Silver Skillet
posts.note: Silver Skillet is a go-to for Southern breakfasts since 1956 with country-fried fare set in vintage decor. They've been serving all the stick-to-your-ribs classics, including the famed Lemon Icebox Pie and grits and ham. You need to order the biscuits or the pies. From the Atlanta Eater website, 'In the world of the classic greasy spoon, the Silver Skillet has been described as Atlanta's benchmark for its quaint quality along with a menu filled with Atlanta favorites like eggs, grits, red-eye gravy, and an award-winning lemon icebox pie. Nestled between Westside and Midtown, two of Atlanta's most progressive dining neighborhoods, the historic diner has offered its customers a consistent Southern dining experience for over 56 years.'

posts.name: Southern Soul Barbeque
posts.note: Southern Soul Barbeque is located in a former gas station is now a bustling Southern BBQ joint serving oak-smoked meat and other specialties. From Food Network website, 'At Southern Soul Barbeque they like their ribs sweet, and they mean sweet. Each rib gets coated in brown sugar and tupelo honey. The result is super tender ribs and pulled pork with a unique woody smokiness.' From the Southern Living website, 'It's exactly 12.5 miles from Exit 38 on I-95 to the parking lot of Southern Soul Barbeque on St. Simons Island. If you're motoring southward down to the sunny skies of Florida, it's very much worth taking that short detour to see how Harrison Sapp and Griffin Bufkin have transformed an old seaside gas station into a Southern barbecue destination.'

posts.name: Staplehouse
posts.note: Staplehouse is a new American restaurant and bar benefiting a charity, with a reservations-only policy at tables. From their website, ‘if you’ve never experienced the relaxing setting of our garden and patio, now is absolutely the time. Our garden is perfect for a sunny day or a cool evening. The patio is covered and ready to take on any weather. When you arrive outside, you’ll find everything you might need.’ From the Atlanta Eater website, 'Ryan Smith crafts the right-now model of the mid-priced tasting menu, serving a dozen or so constantly evolving courses; dishes might involve modernist mousses and powders but never spiral too far from an end goal of accessible pleasure. Co-owners Jen Hidinger and Kara Hidinger (Smith’s wife) lead the front of house with Southern graciousness.'
posts.hrs: Closed Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday

posts.name: Sublime Doughnuts
posts.note: Sublime Doughnuts is a quaint shop doing donuts in a variety of adventurous flavors like maple-bacon-cheddar and red velvet. From their website, ‘As the creative mind behind Sublime Brands’ distinctive doughnut and bakeshop concept, Founder and Creative Director Kamal Grant demonstrates a love for baking and bringing smiles to customers’ faces that can only be described as awe-inspiring. “I realized at a very young age that sweets make people happy, and that’s what I wanted to do with my life,” recalls Grant.’ From the Atlanta Eater website, ‘One of the first gourmet doughnut shops to hit the scene in Atlanta, Sublime is now a mainstay in Home Park and in Toco Hills. Who doesn’t love a 24-hour doughnut shop serving coffee and ice cream, too? Order the A-Town Cream, a chocolate-glazed, A-shaped doughnut filled with custard, or the ice cream-stuffed doughnut burger. Flavors change frequently here but expect doughnuts like s’mores, Nestle crunch, salt and vinegar, and red velvet to be on the menu. Open 24/7.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Talat Market
posts.note: From the Talat Market website, 'Talat Market is located in the Summerhill neighborhood of Atlanta, Georgia. We grew from a pop-up to a brick-and-mortar restaurant because of the amazing support of our community. Co-owners Parnass Savang and Rod Lassiter cook using Thai technique and featuring local Georgia ingredients. “Talat” means “market” in Thai. So yes, we’re Market Market.' From the Atlanta Eater website, 'Thai Restaurant Talat Market Debuts in Summerhill, and Joins Atlanta’s Takeout Game. While the pandemic may have changed their grand opening plans, former pop-up chefs Parnass Lim Savang and Rod Lassiter see Talat Market opening for takeout as just another challenge to tackle.'
posts.hrs: Closed Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday
